articles.headline: In Somalia, Those Who Feed Off Anarchy Fuel It
articles.snippet: Opportunists who profit from chaos are trying to help bring down the transitional government.
articles.abstract: Opportunists who profit from chaos are trying to help bring down the transitional government.
articles.lead_paragraph: GALKAYO, Somalia — Beyond clan rivalry and Islamic fervor, an entirely different motive is helping fuel the chaos in Somalia: profit.

articles.headline: What’s Really Squeezing the Middle Class?
articles.snippet: Layoffs seem to happen more frequently and workers’ income seems more volatile. The reality may be different.
articles.abstract: Layoffs seem to happen more frequently and workers’ income seems more volatile. The reality may be different.
articles.lead_paragraph: There are two different stories people tend to tell when they’re trying to explain why the middle class is feeling squeezed.

articles.headline: U.S. Wonders if Drug Data Was Accurate
articles.snippet: The F.D.A. is examining whether Eli Lilly provided accurate data about the side effects of the antipsychotic drug Zyprexa.
articles.abstract: The F.D.A. is examining whether Eli Lilly provided accurate data about the side effects of the antipsychotic drug Zyprexa.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Food and Drug Administration is examining whether Eli Lilly & Company provided it with accurate data about the side effects of the antipsychotic drug Zyprexa, a potent medicine that has been linked to weight gain and diabetes.

articles.headline: Presidential Pick in Turkey Is Sign of a Rising Islamic Middle Class
articles.snippet: Turkey’s ruling party chose a presidential candidate with an Islamic background, focusing secular Turks’ worries.
articles.abstract: Turkey’s ruling party chose a presidential candidate with an Islamic background, focusing secular Turks’ worries.
articles.lead_paragraph: ISTANBUL, April 24 — Turkey’s ruling party on Tuesday chose a presidential candidate with an Islamic background, a move that will extend the reach of the party — and the emerging class of devout Muslims it represents — into the heart of Turkey’s secular establishment for the first time.

articles.headline: Move Over G.M., Toyota Is No. 1
articles.snippet: The news that Toyota is now the world’s largest carmaker was met in Detroit with anger and a sense of resignation.
articles.abstract: The news that Toyota is now the world’s largest carmaker was met in Detroit with anger and a sense of resignation.
articles.lead_paragraph: DETROIT, April 24 — A quarter century ago, people in this city not only bashed the surging Japanese car companies with words, they also vented their frustration by swinging sledgehammers at Japanese cars, a way for some to raise money for charity (three swings for $1 at one event).

articles.headline: States Seek Limits on ‘Robocalls’ in Campaigns
articles.snippet: Lawmakers in several states want to restrict automated phone calls to voters, some of which have caused outrage.
articles.abstract: Lawmakers in several states want to restrict automated phone calls to voters, some of which have caused outrage.
articles.lead_paragraph: LINCOLN, Neb. — State investigators here are still trying to figure out who sabotaged Scott Kleeb’s campaign for Congress last November with a barrage of automated telephone calls to voters. The unauthorized calls, officials said, distorted Mr. Kleeb’s views and even used a recording of his voice — sometimes arriving in the middle of the night — with the greeting: “Hi, this is Scott Kleeb!”

articles.headline: Wall St. Firm Will Settle Sex Bias Suit
articles.snippet: Morgan Stanley agreed to pay $46 million to settle a suit by female brokers who said they were discriminated against in how they were trained, promoted and paid.
articles.abstract: Morgan Stanley agreed to pay $46 million to settle a suit by female brokers who said they were discriminated against in how they were trained, promoted and paid.
articles.lead_paragraph: For years, sex discrimination lawsuits against Wall Street firms were almost guaranteed to include details of crude antics, pornography and strip clubs.

articles.headline: No Charges for Apple Over Options
articles.snippet: Regulators said they would bring no civil charges against Apple over the backdating of executive stock options.
articles.abstract: Regulators said they would bring no civil charges against Apple over the backdating of executive stock options.
articles.lead_paragraph: Federal securities regulators said yesterday that they would bring no civil charges against Apple over the backdating of executive stock options. But they stopped short of removing the cloud that for nearly a year has hung over the company’s chief executive, Steven P. Jobs.
